content.description: On the leftmost edge of the west-facing wall, at the bottom of the gully that leads up to Ben Dover Face, there's a downward pointing V block about 20 ft left of Fun With A Gun.  White Fang ascends the crack that goes up the right side of that tooth-like V block, over a bulge, past easy ledges, and tops out over a small roof.  Gear anchor placements about 15 ft back and TR setup would require long extension.
content.protection: Pro to 3", gear anchor.

content.description: Fun 5.8 friction on gorgeous rock.  Some topos list the rappel from here as 85 feet, but a 50m rope does NOT get you to the ground.  It gets you to a ledge, from which the ten-foot downclimb is not difficult.
content.protection: You can optionally get a trad placement in some horizontals below the first bolt.  I recommend doing so, because there's some 5.7ish friction between the horizontal and the first bolt.  Two bolts to a chain anchor.

content.description:
This route starts off the ledge system to the right of

Hot Knife

(5.10a). Take care getting to the ledge - that can be a climb in itself. This route is short but fun and has two bolts; getting a foot into the obvious pocket is the challenge.
content.protection: Two bolts, gear to 2.5" for an anchor

climbs.name: Swing Low
climbs.fa: Tim Pinar, Brett Pinar, Frazier Haney, Todd Gordon, July 2004

content.description:
Starts about five feet to right of

R. A. F.

. Climb a ramp to the first bolt on the arete. Follow the remaining bolts to the anchor. Always stay to the right of

R. A. F.

.
content.protection: Five bolts to a two bolt anchor with rings.

climbs.name: The Sound of One Shoe Tapping
climbs.fa: Larry Kuechlin, Jr. and Cory Zinngrabe, November 1988

content.description: Fun 5.8 friction on gorgeous rock.  Some topos list the rappel from here as 85 feet, but a 50m rope does NOT get you to the ground.  It gets you to a ledge, from which the ten-foot downclimb is not difficult.
content.protection: Three bolts to an anchor consisting of rings attached to bolt hangers with screw-links or Maillons. Optional placement in some horizontals below the first bolt, but the climbing isn't too tough or scary if you skip this.

content.description:
This south facing face climb is far up in the cove just right of

Hang Ten

. Thin steep edging on sharp painful things past 6 bolts - a tip ripper.
content.protection: Very well protected by 6 x 3/8" button head bolts, wrap a boulder at the top for an anchor.
content.location: Descent is either to down climb a moderate crack to southeast or a less technical descent is to go scramble west and up to the top of the rock then down climb west near the top of RAF, continue walking north and west and all the way back around.

content.description: This route climbs a crack line just right of Fun Stuff and ends at the same chain anchors.  Half way up a horizontal crack is encountered.  Above this is what I want to warn people about.  5-15 feet above the horizontal crack the rock becomes near vertical and very loose.  I felt the rocks shift as I pulled down on them.  The route accepted gear well until the end when the crack flares out and veres to the right. Stay calm and keep moving, fist jams and hidden holds provide access to the summit.
content.protection: Small nuts and 0.5 - 1.5 cams (#2 at the top before exiting the crack).  A few small tri-cams are useful.  Shares the chain anchors on top of Fun Stuff.

climbs.name: R. A. F.
climbs.fa: Dave Houser and Alan Winter, January 1976

content.description:
Locate the tall face where The Sound of One Shoe Tapping and W. A. C. converge; this route is on the second rock to the right.  You can access the top of the rock via a fourth-class gully left of the face.

R. A. F. is the rightmost of two routes that diverge near the first bolt; Penelope Street (aka Battle of Britain), 5.10a/b, is the left of the two.

Nice friction, with the cruxy moves only slightly above bolts.
content.protection: Three bolts.

content.description: Top rope the seam, a few feet left of "Hot Knife".
content.protection: Top rope.

content.description:
Seen from afar as a striking thin crack, closer inspection reveals this to be a mere seam at the start with somewhat marginal protection. Once past the bouldery start the angle relents and the seam widens into a nice finger crack that eats gear and, unfortunately, is over far too quickly.

Seldom led due to the committing nature of the crux moves - a fall will likely plant you on the sloping ledge at the base, but easily toproped from the anchors of nearby Swing Low.
content.protection: thin to 2", bolted anchor/rap (shared with Swing Low)
content.location:
Located just to the right of

Swing Low

and two routes to the right of

R. A. F.

climbs.name: Pigs on the Wing
climbs.fa: Bob Gaines and Charlie Peterson, January 1992

content.description:
Begin just left of

Porky Pig

, and climb up to a short, right-slanting crack (pro here), then step up to the first bolt. Make crux slab moves up to a second bolt, where you'll find some bigger edges and a few 5.10 moves, followed by an easy, low angle slab to the top.

A bit gritty and scary up to the second bolt!
content.protection: A .75 inch CD for the start, 2 bolts, then 2 to 3 inch CDs for the anchor.

climbs.name: Pepasan
climbs.fa: Todd Gordon and Radim Bedin, May 1991

content.description:
Locate the tall face where The Sound of One Shoe Tapping and W. A. C. converge; this route is on the next rock to the right.

Pepasan starts (and stays) left of the short crack towards the bottom of the rock.  Gain the horizontal (easy climbing), then make a scary, committing, wide step onto a small ledge on the bottom of the face.  Up past three bolts; somewhat runout between second and third.
content.protection: 3 bolts.  Committing, dangerous move to get onto face proper below first bolt without a cam.

climbs.name: Hot Knife
climbs.fa: Paul Piana and Todd Skinner, March 1981

content.description: This short route has a weird but fun lieback crux near the start.  The crux is unprotected, but near the ground; the climb could be soloed.
content.protection: a crash pad or a light rack for the crack above the crux
content.location: at the right end of the smooth face that contains R.A.F.

content.description:
This is the crack and chimney system right of The Sound of One Shoe Tapping and W. A. C.

The traditional rating is 5.2, but the chimney moves for the exit sequence are probably more 5.4ish.

If you're not leading 5.8 friction, this is a good route to hang a toprope on the aforementioned routes.
content.protection: Medium to largish trad gear to a shared chain anchor.

content.description: This route is to the right of "Tofu"... Be careful getting to the ledge at the base of the route. Climb the obvious crack. There's good protection all the way.
content.protection: standard rack

climbs.name: Hang Ten
climbs.fa: Howard Doyle and Herb Laeger, December 1977

content.description: This is a steep face and crack; not sustained.  It's a bit to the right of Tofu The Dwarf and Palm-u-Granite, and starts from the ground.  Climbing over a small roof is the crux - continue up a groove above.
content.protection: standard rack

content.description:
Climb up to a low bolt left of

Fun Stuff,

then move right to clip the bolt on that route before heading up the face above to a prominent horizontal crack and a right-facing corner.

Fun Stuff

moves right into the corner while this route continues up the improbable face above on featured rock with surprisingly good gear.
content.protection: 2 bolts (3/8"), gear to 3 inches

climbs.name: Fun Stuff
climbs.fa: Herb Laeger and Howard Doyle, December 1977

content.description:
Climb smooth slab directly to a single bolt on the face into a leaning, right-facing dihedral that dies out below the top where a few grainy face moves gain the anchors.

Note - The start of this route is somewhat bold with a solitary bolt roughly 20 feet off the ground, which means the lower bolt of

Fun With a Gun

is most often clipped as well.
content.protection:
1 bolt, gear to 2.5 inches, bolted anchor with rings

The lower bolt to the left is technically not on route but is often clipped for a total of 2 bolts.
content.location: This route faces the corralled parking area and climbs a face to right-facing dihedral on the leftmost buttress.

content.description: This is a fun toprope route, with a thin face crux.  It's at the left end of the southwest face of Echo Cove North.
content.protection: toprope problem - you only need gear for the two bolt anchor on top
content.location: Between Fun Stuff and Raging Intensity.

content.description:
Trough to the left of The Sound of One Shoe Tapping and W.A.C.  Easier than Helix (and easier to protect, if you want), this is probably the best bet for climbers who want to hang a toprope on those two 5.8s.

Some scrambling up large flakes and ledges get you into the wide chute for which (I assume) the climb is named.  Solid toe jams and stemming will get you up to just below the chain anchors, and a short step across gets you to the top.

Even at 5.2, this is a pretty fun way to spend 5 or 10 minutes.
content.protection: Thin to medium pieces will protect the crack at the back of the trough on the upper half of the climb. There is no bolted anchor for this route, but you can choose to continue this climb to a two bolt anchor with rap chains on the neighboring 5.8 climb 15 feet away.

climbs.name: Battle of Britain (aka Penelope Street)
climbs.fa: (TR) Bob Gaines & Penny Fogel, 12/89, FL: Dave Haber & Sheryl Haber, 5/92

content.description: This is a steep, well-protected thin face.  It was formerly known as Penelope Street.  Start up R.A.F. and then move left.
content.protection: 4 bolts
